My grandfather was a country doctor, and he indeed worked for chicken eggs and all sorts of other items on barter. Of course, this was 1930s rural America, not modern-day America. Most people nowadays, even in the country, use cash.  Incredibly, country folks know the difference between a doctor and a dentist, whether or not they can afford to visit one. Why, they even have computers and everything!

There was so much stereotyping, it wasn't funny. No, I take that back. It was funny.  It was as if the writer pulled characters out of 1960s comedies like The Andy Griffith Show, Petticoat Junction, and Green Acres and stuck them in a modern drama. Otis was there -- no kidding!  If you like the idea of the plot -- city slicker doctor meets rural small town -- watch Doc Hollywood. It's a comedy that's actually light-hearted, funny, and well-acted. Or if you don't mind subtitles, watch La Grande Sduction (2003-not the new one). Again, it's a comedy.  This plot line is better as a comedy than as a drama.

The best thing I can say about Country Remedy is that it was free, because it was on Prime.  The actresses who played the mayor and her daughter were charming, so points for that.  The scenery was nice.  Clearly, many people enjoyed it immensely. I'm just not one of them ... but I have a lot of respect for rural America.

First and foremost, most small towns would have a doctor IN TOWN because that's where he'd be needed most (or she). Second, the building itself - c'mon - even in the poorest of towns, you wouldn't have a freakin SHACK for a medical clinic. You may have a trailer, but at least you wouldn't literally see daylight through the wall boards. Lastly, and I skip over a hundred idiotic assumptions made by those glamorous folk in H-wood.... North Carolina has the Kate B. Reynolds Trust and the Duke Endowment. While we have medically underserved areas, those two trusts cover the entire state and would easily have granted funding to a town to have a building that could at very minimum afford a BP cuff, not to mention a better suited shack. One day, these imbeciles in movies will climb down off their castle and actually take a good look at the country without judgmental eyeballs. The movie was filmed in Brevard, NC, and even in dem dar hills, we gots us some medikul fasilitees.

The down side.  The over the top use of stereotype Southern characters at the beginning of the movie was irksome.  I would have stopped watching it the early on the first time I watched it if the lead characters had not been so engaging.  Fortunantly you finally get to see the person and not the stereotype poor country folk fairly quickly into the movie.  The ending, which I won't reveal, shows the supporting characters as the decent, friendly, supportive and caring people that more closely resemble the people I know in the rural South.  The climax was kind of 'eh' but given the movie it fit perfectly.  Get some popcorn, someone you love, hope for a rainy day and sit back and enjoy.

I'm from Chicago and have traveled to and through many states. With the exception of NY every state I have been in has a town like the one portrayed in this movie. I live about an hour from San Francisco and within 15 minutes from here there are a lot of towns like the one in this movie. I say all this because it felt unfair seeing all those negative reviews about the movie. I know from my own experience that being low income or very low income can make a doctors visit not feel worth it. When you're uneducated you don't know if the doctor is being genuine with your diagnosis. It can just as easily be said that the medical industry will say you need this treatment or lab work and other tests just to make more money. I went to the ER with no insurance and was billed $36,000 for the few hours I was there even though all I was given was an antibiotic, fluids, EKG test and chest x-ray.

Sorry for anyone who thought my review was a waste of space. I just thought the accurate portrayal of how it can be difficult in small towns in the middle of nowhere needed to be stated as still a current issue. I'm sure a lot of places have boomed over the last two decades but many are also suffering more now than before.

Country Remedy (a.k.a. Simple Things) generates this Hallmark Channel vibe, and that's not a bad thing. Country Remedy is an indie family drama with many flashes of humor. In a way, it's a more sober take on Michael J. Fox's similarly-veined comedy, Doc Hollywood. They're both essentially about an ambitious big city doctor who somehow end up in a small hick town he can't wait to get out of.

Dr. Evan Gibbs (Cameron Bancroft) is a three-months-widowed doctor from Chicago. He's now raising his 10-year-old son Nate (Aidan Mitchell) on his own, and he wants to do right by the kid. But his paternal instincts are warring with his career ambitions. At his hospital he's jonesing for that promotion to head of the Pediatrician Department. As a stepping stone to securing that post, his boss tasks Gibbs with spending the summer at the remote mountain town of Dunn's Rock, North Carolina and opening a clinic there.

In Dunn's Rock Dr. Gibbs is aghast at the rickety shack masquerading as his clinic (and that's even before he finds out about the rats). He's not off at the best start as he gets on the wrong footing with the pretty town mayor (Bellamy Young) whom he initially assumes (and scolds) as his nurse. Yeah, son, Dr. Gibbs embodies the worst of the big city doctor stereotypes. He is callous and condescending and pompous and oh so awkward in his interactions with the hardy locals. That town hall meeting made me cringe. When he bemoans the lack of his office's medical equipment, the mayor pretty much tells him to improvise and make do, her own tactful version of shut-up juice.

Predictably, it's tough times for the doc. Dunn's Rock is slow to warm to newcomers and generally untrusting of physicians. It's deep into the film before Dr. Gibbs gains enough trust within the obstinate community that he's able to build up a clientele. And it's a colorful community to draw from: from the routinely inebriated handyman (Mickey Jones) and the fiercely self-sufficient pregnant hillbilly woman (Amber Benson, from BtVS) and the shiftless father of her child to the mayor herself and her tomboy daughter (Channing Nichols) and her taciturn pal (Zac Gardner).

It's a story that you've seen before and time and again. But the key moments come off well, with Bellamy Young simply wonderful (and naturally gorgeous) as the insightful mayor. Familiar themes are addressed, that of coming to terms with loss and reconnecting and acclimating to strange environments and easing up and taking it all in. Somewhen, Dr. Gibbs gets over himself and settles into the leisurely rhythms of Dunn's Rock. And are you so surprised that the movie title refers not to what Dr. Gibbs doles out to his patients but to healing that's applied to the good doctor himself? He's got a savvy boss back there in Chicago.

One thing. Dr. Gibbs' icebreaker at the town hall meeting: "Have you heard the one about the two rednecks and the rooster?" I wish that stone-cold crowd ahad let Dr. Gibbs finish that joke.

Another thing: Did the movie set up Dr. Gibbs' son as asthmatic before that climactic scene? Because, to me, it seemed to come out of nowhere. Maybe they established that when I went to raid the fridge (shout out to tuna melt sandwich!).

I have now lived in city and country, love them both, and appreciate the gifts of a slower pace of life. Today I'm sitting in my office, surrounded by paperwork and deadlines, and I keep thinking about this film.

Sometimes a movie is really worth seeing - even more than once.  In this film, the elements of life that are real and connect us to others - our work, our families, our friends, love and grief- are brought together in a story that pulls us back again and again to its simple and eternal truths. This is a film for the whole family - but make sure there is a tissue handy to wipe away the tears even as you smile with the joy you will experience.

I'm from Chicago and have traveled to and through many states. With the exception of NY every state I have been in has a town like the one portrayed in this movie. I live about an hour from San Francisco and within 15 minutes from here there are a lot of towns like the one in this movie. I say all this because it felt unfair seeing all those negative reviews about the movie. I know from my own experience that being low income or very low income can make a doctors visit not feel worth it. When you're uneducated you don't know if the doctor is being genuine with your diagnosis. It can just as easily be said that the medical industry will say you need this treatment or lab work and other tests just to make more money. I went to the ER with no insurance and was billed $36,000 for the few hours I was there even though all I was given was an antibiotic, fluids, EKG test and chest x-ray.

Sorry for anyone who thought my review was a waste of space. I just thought the accurate portrayal of how it can be difficult in small towns in the middle of nowhere needed to be stated as still a current issue. I'm sure a lot of places have boomed over the last two decades but many are also suffering more now than before.

All kidding aside, the film features an interesting cast and is competently acted, but the writers didn't give them much to work with. It's just cliche after cliche. The scenes with the basement stairs kind of made me wonder whether whether this couldn't be re-edited as a horror movie... "The Remedy." Honestly, though, I think the story of how the pocket watch came to be a compass is probably more interesting.

We all with children know how hard it can be to find a decent happy feel good movie for family movie nights. Came across this movie, thought based on the vague description that it was going to be about a father and son taking a trip and the father realizing he had been working too much and that he needed to make more time for his son, they come back home with a new understanding of each other and a stronger bond Yada yada yada.....the movie starts out with this young boy dressed for his mothers funeral. They do go on a trip together where the father leaves the boy alone in the house (a run down cabin on a mountain) they are staying at while he goes to work and it shows the son hearing all the weird sounds a strange house can make and it shows him being scared. I think in the movie, the boy is 10 years old. It also shows him making a wish for something to happen to a bully and then later the bully is having to be rushed to hospital and is near death. It then shows a lady going in to labor but something is wrong and has blood all down front of her dress. The baby is born, all is well. The boy whose father leaves him alone, makes friends. It shows that the boy has asthma. It shows the boy taking off into the woods without his inhaler, stopping reaching for his inhaler while getting ready to start gasping for air, the scene immediately changes to the newborn baby's father putting his hand on the baby and the baby not moving and him telling the mother something was wrong that the baby wasn't moving. That's when we turned it off quickly!
I just don't get why when you find a movie that doesn't have all the bad language, violent and/or sexual stuff in it, you get movies that mess with a child's emotions in such a negative way. Maybe this movie got a little more positive toward the end but based on all we saw just in the beginning, we wasn't going to watch to find out.

Country Remedy (a.k.a. Simple Things) generates this Hallmark Channel vibe, and that's not a bad thing. Country Remedy is an indie family drama with many flashes of humor. In a way, it's a more sober take on Michael J. Fox's similarly-veined comedy, Doc Hollywood. They're both essentially about an ambitious big city doctor who somehow end up in a small hick town he can't wait to get out of.

Dr. Evan Gibbs (Cameron Bancroft) is a three-months-widowed doctor from Chicago. He's now raising his 10-year-old son Nate (Aidan Mitchell) on his own, and he wants to do right by the kid. But his paternal instincts are warring with his career ambitions. At his hospital he's jonesing for that promotion to head of the Pediatrician Department. As a stepping stone to securing that post, his boss tasks Gibbs with spending the summer at the remote mountain town of Dunn's Rock, North Carolina and opening a clinic there.

In Dunn's Rock Dr. Gibbs is aghast at the rickety shack masquerading as his clinic (and that's even before he finds out about the rats). He's not off at the best start as he gets on the wrong footing with the pretty town mayor (Bellamy Young) whom he initially assumes (and scolds) as his nurse. Yeah, son, Dr. Gibbs embodies the worst of the big city doctor stereotypes. He is callous and condescending and pompous and oh so awkward in his interactions with the hardy locals. That town hall meeting made me cringe. When he bemoans the lack of his office's medical equipment, the mayor pretty much tells him to improvise and make do, her own tactful version of shut-up juice.

Predictably, it's tough times for the doc. Dunn's Rock is slow to warm to newcomers and generally untrusting of physicians. It's deep into the film before Dr. Gibbs gains enough trust within the obstinate community that he's able to build up a clientele. And it's a colorful community to draw from: from the routinely inebriated handyman (Mickey Jones) and the fiercely self-sufficient pregnant hillbilly woman (Amber Benson, from BtVS) and the shiftless father of her child to the mayor herself and her tomboy daughter (Channing Nichols) and her taciturn pal (Zac Gardner).

It's a story that you've seen before and time and again. But the key moments come off well, with Bellamy Young simply wonderful (and naturally gorgeous) as the insightful mayor. Familiar themes are addressed, that of coming to terms with loss and reconnecting and acclimating to strange environments and easing up and taking it all in. Somewhen, Dr. Gibbs gets over himself and settles into the leisurely rhythms of Dunn's Rock. And are you so surprised that the movie title refers not to what Dr. Gibbs doles out to his patients but to healing that's applied to the good doctor himself? He's got a savvy boss back there in Chicago.

One thing. Dr. Gibbs' icebreaker at the town hall meeting: "Have you heard the one about the two rednecks and the rooster?" I wish that stone-cold crowd ahad let Dr. Gibbs finish that joke.

Another thing: Did the movie set up Dr. Gibbs' son as asthmatic before that climactic scene? Because, to me, it seemed to come out of nowhere. Maybe they established that when I went to raid the fridge (shout out to tuna melt sandwich!).

QUICK SYNOPSIS

The big city doctor is going through one mental crisis while his ten-year-old son is going through his own mental challenges, both dealing with the death of their wife and mother.

Meanwhile, the doctor has been given a deal, spend the summer in a small town in the mountains area of North Carolina and he'll get a big promotion at work. Most people know that by the end of the movie, he will stay where he is needed, but there are plenty of surprises along the way.

It's the surprises that make this a wonderful movie. It's a big change of lifestyle to move from Chicago to ultra-rural North Carolina, and the citizenry have to take their time deciding to trust the new-fangled city-slicker of a doctor, while some of the kids of the area have to decide whether to like or hate his son.

Do get this movie. You'll love it. Or watch it with free downloading on Amazon Prime, like I did. You'll be glad you did.

I grew up in rural North Carolina - not the mountains, but a small town. The characters are true-to-life; some are like folks I know. Where I spent the summers, I used to worry about getting a snake bite, because of the distance to any kind of medical care - a situation that fortunately didn't materialize. I have now lived in city and country, love them both, and appreciate the gifts of a slower pace of life. Today I'm sitting in my office, surrounded by paperwork and deadlines, and I keep thinking about this film.

Sometimes a movie is really worth seeing - even more than once. I would have never watched this movie if Amber Benson were not in it. On appearance it looks like so many other trope filled, overly wrought fluff movies. And sometimes it is- the film has some serious holes. It is trope-y and predictable at times, the doctor basically brushes aside the fact that a young girl is having grand mal seizures so there can be a joke about trading medical care for cucumbers. And it is completely white-washed. But there is something really special about this movie- and I think its because the acting and directing are very very good. The lead especially, infuses so many layers and depth to his performance. The entire cast is great, all moving beyond their stereotypical roles and bringing about fully fleshed out characters,  language that could be flat is full of life and meaning, and because of that ,we are drawn in.
